commentary.line: So, that's all we have from this game. Many thanks for your company folks. Tomorrow, South Africa will lock horns with UAE in Wellington. So make sure, you join us for that game. On behalf of Krishna, Raju, Sriram, my co-commentators, Akshay, Srivathsa and Pradeep, this is Sidhant Maheshwari, signing off. Take care. Ciao!
Let's glance through some of the tweets from this game:
@sachin_rt: 4 in a row, Congrats @KumarSanga2 Amazing batting and super consistency #CWC15
@anilkumble1074: Run machine Sanga... Plenty of fuel in the tank...Well done! #respect #CWC2015
@IamDimuth: It will take four centuries to find another player like @KumarSanga2 Hats off #legend #4inarow #ICCWC #SLvSCO #CWC15
@legsidelizzy: Someone needs to pass a law that stops Sangakkara from retiring. @UN ?
@jatinsapru: Sangakkara's ploy to retire is unfair to the game! He's not blocking any talent, is in prime form, so then why? Let's file a petition #cwc15
@cricketaakash: Hail Sanga #Legend

Mathews: 'I have got a sore achilles tendon, so the management and the physio thought it was wise to stay out of the field. It was a precautionary effort. I don't think so, it was pretty sore and the physio thought not to risk it and stay out of the field. So, we got assess it for the next couple of days. Looking from the dressing room, it is pretty different than being out there in the middle, but I think the boys played really well. Credit should go to Dilshan and Sangakkara. Sangakkara is getting better and better with each and every game. It's wonderful to have these guys in the team. We just got to take it one game at a time, whoever we get to play, take it as another game, play positive cricket, that we have been doing pretty well in the past 4 games and we just have to go out there and play the same game. If we can improve out bowling and also the fielding quite a bit, it will be a great thing going forward. But I think the batters have been performing really well, getting 300 four times in a row is not easy. I have almost gone on my knees and begged him not to retire. But, unfortunately he has called it a day, so we got to respect his decision. He has served the team, the country for such a long time and we are really thankful for their service (on being asked if there's any possibilty that he could convince Sangakkara not to retire).'

Mommsen: 'We got a nice partnership together there, gave ourselves a bit of a platform. Slightly disappointed that we couldn't push hard and get the game deeper. Very disappointed, I think that was a brilliant wicket there but not to go on and get a bigger score is slightly disappointing. Huge amount, today was a huge learning experience, playing against some of the best batters in the world and the way they go about their business. The calmness of their innings is brilliant to watch and learn from. For the bowlers, obviously very difficult, very testing on a very good batting wicket. So, huge amounts of learning happened today. No. 1, for the player we have played against definitely (on where he rates Sangakkara in terms of the best players in the world). They'll have to, this is the level, this is the standard we want to compete at. We want to play against the full members more often and it's important now that we compete at that level. So, we are learning as much as possible day in and day out during this World Cup and today was a brilliant day for learning.'

Sangakkara: 'Very slowly (on being asked how he gets rid of all his gear after the match). It was a pretty good game, it was important that we finished off strong and playing against a team like Scotland, it is sometimes easy to take things or be a bit complacent. But, today I think the boys were right up for a fight and although the Scots fought hard, we were better on the day. That's what I have been doing for quite a long time, once you get used to a certain routine, it becomes hard of course and now that I am 37, I get a bit slower, the joints start creaking and aching. But I am pretty happy that I am still playing. I consider myself very, very lucky to be a part of such a good side. So, when everything is going well, things look bright. (Laughs loudly) It's hard to say, sometimes things just fall into place, everything clicks. No matter how hard you try to find that one thing, it is difficult to pinpoint it. Maybe, it is because I am making a lot of better decisions, the right decision at the right time, taking the risk at the right time, being more calculated, being a bit more positive in my approach. I don't really know what that one thing is, but whatever it is, it is working for me at the moment and I would like to hold onto that for as long as I can. As long as we our positive, as long as we enjoy ourselves, as long as we believe that we can do it, I think we can go far (on being asked if Sri Lanka can go all the way). We have had a strange World Cup, I think our squad has changed quite a lot from the start. We had a lot of injuries, but the real key for us is the way we enjoy our cricket, the flair with which we play, the brand of cricket we play. As long as there is a smile on our faces and as long as we give everything on the field, we always have a chance. That's what we look at and that's what we believe. I would love to see myself, I would love to see all of us there. We have really got to break it down. If it happens, it happens. You can't worry too much, you just got to keep your focus on the present. Couple of days off, regroup, train hard and play a very good quarter-final. If we are good enough on the day, we will get to the semi-final. So, we will concentrate on that game and if we make it through, I will talk to you again and I will have a bigger smile.'
Kumar Sangakkara is the Man of the Match for his outstanding 95-ball 124.

Earlier, Dilshan and Sangakkara added 195 for the second wicket to set up a massive total. The former got his second ton of the competition while the latter notched up his 4th consecutive hundred and became the first batsman to achieve that. Mathews bettered Dinesh Chandimal's record of the fastest Sri Lankan to a World Cup fifty by getting it in 20 balls. They would have got plenty more, if they didn't lose wickets in a heap. Scotland will take on the mighty Aussies next and Sri Lanka will have some time off before they play the quarter-final.

Sri Lanka's bowling still has some work to do and they have to get it right as the next game they play is the quarter-final. Malinga looks like a shadow of his old self, Kulasekara is not troubling the batsmen with his indippers. They also failed to strike in the middle overs, they are missing a quality spinner. Chameera was quick, but he didn't have control, he came back well though in the second spell to pick up 3 wickets. So, they need to sort it out, if they have to beat any one of the top teams.

Both batsmen got to their fifties. And they were excellent against the spin of Prasanna, using their feet and playing it right under the eyes. It was Scotland's second 100 plus partnership in World Cups and Mommsen was involved in both of them. However, the duo went in quick succession. Berrington came out attacking and hit a few lusty blows, but he kept losing partners and they were finally bowled out for 215.

The centurion from the previous game, Kyle Coetzer went for a second ball duck today. Scotland were in a bit of trouble early on as MacLeod once again failed to capitalise on the opportunity given. Machan battled for a while before being trapped by Dilshan, he also lost the review in the process. After that, Mommsen and Coleman batted sensibly to add a 118-run stand for the 4th wicket.

43.1   Dushmantha Chameera to Davey, out Caught by Thirimanne!! Sri Lanka win by a massive margin of 148 runs. Scotland have been bowled out and Chameera picks up his third wicket. It was a back of a length delivery just outside off, Davey pushes at it, gets an outside edge that is well caught by Thirimanne at slip, who moves across low to his left to complete the catch. The Sri Lankan players walk off the field as they shake hands with their Scottish counterparts. Davey c Thirimanne b Dushmantha Chameera 4(7)
Dushmantha Chameera to Davey, THATS OUT!! Caught!!

42.6   Malinga to Alasdair Evans, no run, low full toss just outside off, Evans looks to clear the man at mid-on, but doesn't time it at all, the ball goes on the bounce to Chameera, who was right at the edge of the circle
42.5   Malinga to Davey, 1 run, angling in on the pads, Davey flicks it uppishly through the vacant mid-wicket region for a single

42.4   Malinga to Davey, no run, slower full toss that was dipping in on the leg stump, Davey backs away and just about gets his bat down in time to push it back towards the bowler, had he missed, it would have crashed into the stumps

42.3   Malinga to Davey, 2 runs, slower length delivery just outside off, Davey goes for the loft over cover, doesn't get hold of it properly, but it is good enough to go over the infield and the batsmen take two before the fielder from cover chases it down
42.2   Malinga to Davey, no run, full and outside off, Davey leans forward and knocks it into the off-side

42.1   Malinga to Davey, no run, loopy full toss down leg, Davey moves slightly across but fails to tickle it fine, the ball dips and just about misses the leg stump there, good ball first up in the new over

41.6   Dushmantha Chameera to Davey, 1 run, back of a length delivery on the pads, Davey hops up in the crease and tucks it away towards mid-wicket, there was a slight hesitation as the batsmen went for the single, but the batsman makes it in time at the non-striker's end even as the fielder has a shy at the stumps
41.5   Dushmantha Chameera to Alasdair Evans, 1 run, back of a length delivery just outside off, Evans waits inside the crease, opens the face of the bat and runs it down to third man
41.4   Dushmantha Chameera to Alasdair Evans, no run, full delivery on leg, Evans turns it to short mid-wicket
41.3   Dushmantha Chameera to Alasdair Evans, no run, yorker on the stumps, Evans jams it out
41.2   Dushmantha Chameera to Alasdair Evans, no run, short delivery just outside off, Evans drops his wrists and lets it pass
Alasdair Evans, right handed bat, comes to the crease

41.1   Dushmantha Chameera to Berrington, out Caught by N Kulasekara!! Another one goes down and Kulasekara just about manages to hold onto the catch. It was fuller and outside off, Berrington was trying to clear the man at mid-on there, but can't get the elevation. He ends up hitting it straight to Kula, who just about drops it as the ball popped out of his hands, but he used his body well to hold onto the catch. Berrington c N Kulasekara b Dushmantha Chameera 29(22) [4s-2 6s-2]
Dushmantha Chameera to Berrington, THATS OUT!! Caught!!
Scotland have lost their last 4 wickets for just 20 runs

40.6   Malinga to Berrington, 1 run, just short of a good length and just outside off, Berrington was early into the punch, but manages to get it square of the wicket and that's good enough for a single
Josh Davey, right handed bat, comes to the crease

40.5   Malinga to Rob Taylor, out Caught by T Perera!! Taylor's short stay at the crease comes to an end. It was a back of a length slower delivery outside off, Taylor clears the front leg and wanted to loft it over mid-on, he was too early into the shot and mistimes it completely off the toe-end of the bat, the ball goes towards mid-on, who moves back a little and takes a simple catch. The Scottish are falling apart here. Rob Taylor c T Perera b Malinga 3(6)
Malinga to Rob Taylor, THATS OUT!! Caught!!

40.4   Malinga to Rob Taylor, 2 runs, slower ball and length delivery around off, Taylor was early into the loft, gets it off the toe-end of the bat and the ball just about clears a backtracking mid-on, the batsmen take two
40.3   Malinga to Rob Taylor, no run, short delivery outside off, Taylor backs away and goes for the flat-batted pull, but the ball goes under his bat and through to the keeper
40.2   Malinga to Rob Taylor, no run, down the leg-side, Taylor fails to tickle it fine, the ball clips the pad on its way to the keeper, who dives to his right and stops the ball
40.1   Malinga to Rob Taylor, no run, good slower ball yorker on middle stump, Taylor did well to get his bat down in time as he squeezed it out
The batting powerplay yielded 19/3. Sri Lanka have come back strongly in those five overs

39.6   Dushmantha Chameera to Berrington, FOUR, full delivery just outside off, Berrington drills it back to the right of the bowler, who tries to catch it, but the ball goes past his hands and beats the fielder at mid-off as well, who had no chance of cutting that off
39.5   Dushmantha Chameera to Rob Taylor, 1 run, tucks this delivery on middle stump line towards mid-wicket

39.5   Dushmantha Chameera to Berrington, no ball, 1 run, that's loose from Chameera, it was a high full toss around waist height, the square leg umpire signalled it a no-ball for height as Berrington helps it away down to fine leg for a single, Chameera must have been given a warning as well
Rob Taylor, left handed bat, comes to the crease

39.4   Dushmantha Chameera to Matthew Cross, out Caught by Sangakkara!! Cross perishes now and it's a great catch by Sangakkara. He can't do anything wrong today. It was short and well outside off, Cross went for the pull, but ends up slicing it high in the air. Sangakkara runs back to his right, gets under it and takes a good catch in the end. These kind of swirlers are difficult, but Sangakkara did well there to take it. First ODI wicket for Chameera as well. Matthew Cross c Sangakkara b Dushmantha Chameera 7(10)
Dushmantha Chameera to Matthew Cross, THATS OUT!! Caught!!

39.3   Dushmantha Chameera to Matthew Cross, no run, yorker on the stumps, Cross looks to squeeze it out, gets an inside edge that rolls behind the stumps towards the keeper, the batsman was looking for the single, but has to rush back in

39.2   Dushmantha Chameera to Matthew Cross, 2 runs, what happened there? It was short and well wide outside off, it was the cross-seamer, the ball got stuck into the wicket and Cross was early into his flat-batted shot, the ball takes the top-edge and balloons over the keeper, the batsmen take two
39.1   Dushmantha Chameera to Berrington, 1 run, banged in short and around off, Berrington jams the pull through mid-wicket for another run
Dushmantha Chameera [5.0-0-39-0] is back into the attack

38.6   Malinga to Matthew Cross, 2 runs, low full toss, Cross made room for himself and wanted to hit it into the off-side, gets an inside edge that rolls away behind square on the on-side, the batsmen take two, had he missed that, the ball would have rattled into the stumps

38.5   Malinga to Matthew Cross, 2 runs, another slower ball from Malinga and that resulted in another wicket, it was on a length and on off, Cross was early into the slog and just about clears mid-on, who was running to his right, the batsmen take two before Chameera hunts it down
38.4   Malinga to Matthew Cross, no run, almost a yorker on middle, Cross jams out the drive to mid-on
38.3   Malinga to Matthew Cross, no run, drives this fullish delivery into the off-side
38.2   Malinga to Matthew Cross, no run, full and outside off, Cross was looking to squeeze it out into the off-side, fails to make contact
Sangakkara now has the most number of dismissals as a wicket-keeper in World Cups. He goes past Adam Gilchrist, who had 52 dismissals to his name.
38.1   Malinga to Matthew Cross, no run, slower ball yorker on off, Cross squeezes it out towards backward point

37.6   N Kulasekara to Matthew Cross, 1 run, yorker on off, Cross jams it out to mid-off, who fumbles the ball and the batsmen charge across for a single, the fielder has a shy at the non-striker's end, but the batsman was well in
Matthew Cross, right handed bat, comes to the crease

37.5   N Kulasekara to M A Leask, out Caught by Sangakkara!! It was another bouncer from Kula, Leask fails to connect with the hook, the umpire doesn't call it a wide. Wait a minute! Sri Lanka have reviewed for a caught behind appeal, there was a little sound as the ball went past the bat and maybe, that's what interested him. Snicko shows a little spike as the ball goes past the bat. The decision has been overturned. Leask has to go. What a review by the Lankans. That review caught everyone by surprise. Nevertheless, Scotland are six down now and the Lankans won't mind it one bit. M A Leask c Sangakkara b N Kulasekara 2(7)
N Kulasekara to M A Leask, THATS OUT!! Caught!!
37.4   N Kulasekara to M A Leask, no run, slower ball bumper from Kulasekara, Leask went for the hook, but can't connect
37.3   N Kulasekara to Berrington, 1 run, yorker outside off, Berrington squeezes out the drive to the left of cover-point, who runs across and puts in the dive, saves three runs for his team

37.2   N Kulasekara to M A Leask, 1 run, just short of a good length and outside off, Leask hangs back and cuts it towards square third man, who moves across to his right and keeps the batsmen down to a single
37.1   N Kulasekara to M A Leask, no run, on a good length and angling in on off, Leask pushes at it off the front foot, gets an inside edge onto the pad
36.6   Malinga to Berrington, no run, loopy yorker from Malinga on off, Berrington squeezes it out
36.5   Malinga to Berrington, no run, slower ball on middle stump line, it was bowled at 110.4kph, Berrington leans forward and defends it into the off-side
36.4   Malinga to Berrington, no run, full toss on the stumps, Berrington defends it to the right of the bowler, the ball rolls away to mid-on

36.3   Malinga to M A Leask, 1 run, a slow, low full toss on middle and leg, Leask was inside the crease, he looks to work it into the on-side, gets an inside edge that dribbles away to fine leg, the batsmen cross over
36.2   Malinga to M A Leask, no run, very full and on leg, Leask fails to clip it into the on-side and wears it on the pad, it was snaking down leg though

36.1   Malinga to M A Leask, no run, slower ball yorker just outside off, Leask was deceived there as he went pushing at it, the ball goes past the blade and the off stump as well, Leask affords a smile after that ball
Lasith Malinga [5.0-0-18-1] is back into the attack
Michael Leask, right handed bat, comes to the crease

35.6   N Kulasekara to Coleman, out Caught by T Perera!! Soft dismissal for Coleman. It was the leg-spinner from Kulasekara, Coleman was looking to launch it over the long-on fence, but he can't time it as it came off the toe-end. The fielder at long-on comes under it and almost drops the simplest of catches as it popped out of his hands, but he did well at the end to hang onto it. Another good knock comes to an end. Coleman c T Perera b N Kulasekara 70(74) [4s-7]
N Kulasekara to Coleman, THATS OUT!! Caught!!

35.5   N Kulasekara to Coleman, no run, 105.8kph slower ball well outside off, Coleman went right across his stumps and was looking to scoop it over short fine, can't connect and the ball rolls away to the keeper

35.4   N Kulasekara to Coleman, no run, slower delivery from Kulasekara, it was a back of a length delivery just outside off, Coleman was early into the pull, the ball doesn't bounce much and goes on the bounce to the keeper, it was not too far away from the off stump too

35.3   N Kulasekara to Berrington, 1 run, full and around off, Berrington waits inside the crease and whips it to the right of long-on, the batsmen take a single before the fielder runs across and fields it
35.2   N Kulasekara to Berrington, no run, just short of a good length and on top of off, Berrington knocks it towards backward point and says 'no' for the single
35.1   N Kulasekara to Berrington, no run, length delivery outside off, it was the off-speed delivery, Berrington was looking to guide it down to third man but fails to connect with it
Nuwan Kulasekara [5.0-0-16-1] is back into the attack
It's batting powerplay time. The umpire makes the signal and the ball has been handed over to Kulasekara, who will start the proceedings after the drinks break.

Time for a drinks break. Scotland have played really well in this period. Mommsen and Coleman were making the Sri Lankan bowlers sweat hard, but Mommsen got out against the run of play to Perera. Since then, Berrington has been aggressive and is giving good company to Coleman. The target is a little too far away, but Scotland will definitely provide us entertainment if they go after it.
34.6   S Prasanna to Berrington, 1 run, touch slower this time and around off stump line, Berrington goes down on one knee and sweeps it to deep square leg

34.5   S Prasanna to Berrington, SIX, mammoth! It was floated up on off, Berrington kneels down and hammers the slog sweep over the long-on fence, that went quite the distance, good shot from Berrington
34.4   S Prasanna to Berrington, no run, darted on the pads, Berrington works it straight to mid-wicket
34.3   S Prasanna to Coleman, 1 run, flighted delivery outside off, Coleman eases it down to long-off and gets off strike
34.2   S Prasanna to Coleman, no run, tossed up around off, Coleman drills the drive towards short cover off the front foot, where Dilshan dives to his left and saves some runs for his team
34.1   S Prasanna to Berrington, 1 run, pushed through down leg, Berrington works it towards backward square leg for a single

33.6   T Perera to Coleman, FOUR, short but not short enough to trouble the batsman, who rocks back and pulls it behind square with ease, it was the slower one and Coleman had all the time in the world to dispatch it to the fence
33.5   T Perera to Coleman, no run, short of length delivery around off, Coleman defends it into the off-side
33.4   T Perera to Coleman, no run, Coleman goes right across his stumps and Perera follows him with a leg-cutter, Coleman can't lay bat on it and the ball just spins away from the batsman's blade

33.3   T Perera to Coleman, no run, just short of a good length and outside off, Coleman goes across and tries to work it through the leg-side, he closes the bat face a little too early, gets a soft leading edge that rolls away towards the bowler
33.2   T Perera to Coleman, no run, slightly fuller and outside off, Coleman drives it to mid-off
33.1   T Perera to Berrington, 1 run, back of a length delivery around off, Berrington stays back and pushes it towards sweeper cover with soft hands, the batsmen take a single
32.6   S Prasanna to Berrington, 1 run, tossed up outside off, Berrington presses forward and drives it to sweeper cover
32.5   S Prasanna to Berrington, no run, flighted delivery just outside off, Berrington defends it into the off-side

32.4   S Prasanna to Berrington, SIX, that's a super shot! It was floated up on off, Berrington kneels down and sweeps it, the ball went up and over the deep square leg fence. That was timed very sweetly

32.3   S Prasanna to Berrington, FOUR, that was a very poor effort from Dilshan at short cover, it was tossed up on the stumps, Berrington drills the drive towards Dilshan, who bends down as he tries to field it, but the ball goes under him and through his legs, crashes into the deep extra cover fence
32.2   S Prasanna to Berrington, no run, in the blockhole just outside off, Berrington jams it out into the off-side
A slip is in place
32.1   S Prasanna to Coleman, 1 run, floated up just outside off, Coleman drives it wide of long-off for a single
Richie Berrington, right handed bat, comes to the crease

31.6   T Perera to Mommsen, out Caught by Thirimanne!! Mommsen goes against the run of play. It was fuller and around off, Mommsen leans forward and drives uppishly, Thirimanne at short cover leans forward to take the catch, but can't hold onto it. Luckily for him, the ball lobs up off his body and he takes it on the second attempt. Still a good effort from the Sri Lankan vice-captain. Perera is delighted and celebrates with his team-mates. Mommsen was very disappointed and was a little late to leave his ground. It was a good knock nevertheless. Mommsen c Thirimanne b T Perera 60(75) [4s-7]
T Perera to Mommsen, THATS OUT!! Caught!!
31.5   T Perera to Coleman, 1 run, length delivery just outside off, Coleman was pushing at it from the crease, gets an outside edge that runs away down to third man
31.4   T Perera to Mommsen, 1 run, angling in on middle, Mommsen waits for it and clips it towards mid-wicket to get off strike
31.4   T Perera to Mommsen, wide, very poor ball from Perera, another slower one and this one is even further away from the tramline, another wide and Sangakkara doesn't look happy with that effort
31.3   T Perera to Mommsen, FOUR, great shot from the Scottish captain, it was short and it sat up nicely for Mommsen to swivel and pull it behind square, the ball rockets away to the fence
31.2   T Perera to Mommsen, no run, length delivery around off, Mommsen leans forward, opens the face of the bat and pushes it to backward point
31.2   T Perera to Mommsen, wide, slower delivery from Perera, but it was well outside the tramline, called a wide by the umpire
31.1   T Perera to Coleman, 1 run, shortish and well outside off, Coleman hangs back and cuts, gets an outside edge that dribbles away to third man
Thisara Perera [5.0-0-27-0] is back into the attack
Thisara Perera has come back on. He replaces Chameera
30.6   S Prasanna to Coleman, 1 run, floated up around off and middle, Coleman backs away and drives it to sweeper cover, he will keep the strike
30.5   S Prasanna to Mommsen, 1 run, quicker and around off, Mommsen knocks it to sweeper cover

30.4   S Prasanna to Mommsen, 2 runs, comes down the track and lofts this flighted delivery just over a leaping short mid-wicket, the fielder from deep mid-wicket runs to his left, puts in the dive and saves two runs for his team right near the boundary, good effort from Kusal Perera there
30.3   S Prasanna to Coleman, 1 run, touch shortish and outside off, Coleman looks to guide it down to third man, but can't beat backward point who dives to his left and stops the ball
30.2   S Prasanna to Mommsen, 1 run, gives the charge and converts this tossed up delivery into a full toss, driven to long-off
30.1   S Prasanna to Mommsen, no run, tossed up just outside off, Mommsen drives it to cover
There is a slight drizzle in the air. Scotland are 66 runs behind after 30 overs (D/L)
29.6   Dushmantha Chameera to Coleman, no run, length delivery outside off, Coleman comes charging down the track and looks to go big, but can't lay bat on it and the keeper gloves it
29.5   Dushmantha Chameera to Coleman, no run, back of a length delivery just outside off, Coleman was looking to run it down to third man, Coleman ends up chopping it towards backward point

29.4   Dushmantha Chameera to Mommsen, 1 run, good shot for just a single, it was a shortish delivery well outside off, Mommsen cuts it hard square of the wicket, but there was a fielder in the deep and it went straight to him
29.3   Dushmantha Chameera to Coleman, 1 run, banged in short and at the batsman, who pulls, but can't time it properly. The batsman take a single as the ball falls in the vacant square leg region

29.2   Dushmantha Chameera to Mommsen, 1 run, Mommsen reaches his 5th ODI fifty with a single, it was a back of a length delivery just around off, Mommsen pushes it square of the wicket and gets to the other end
29.1   Dushmantha Chameera to Mommsen, no run, bowls this one in the channel outside off, Mommsen hangs back and looks to run it down to third man, can't connect and the keeper collects
28.6   S Prasanna to Mommsen, 1 run, a single down to long-off brings up the 100-run stand between these two, this is Preston Mommsen's second 100-run partnership in two games
28.5   S Prasanna to Mommsen, no run, flighted delivery just outside off, Mommsen comes forward and drives to the left of cover, Dilshan runs to his left, dives and prevents the single
28.4   S Prasanna to Coleman, 1 run, gives the charge and drives this tossed up delivery on the stumps to long-off
28.3   S Prasanna to Coleman, no run, pushed through quicker and fuller on middle and leg, Coleman squeezes it out back to the bowler
28.2   S Prasanna to Coleman, no run, floated up outside off, Coleman goes for the front foot drive, gets an outside edge that rolls away towards backward point
28.1   S Prasanna to Coleman, no run, loopy delivery in the blockhole, Coleman drives it to cover
Seekkuge Prasanna [4.0-0-28-0] is back into the attack
Spin after 8 overs as Prasanna replaces Malinga, who just bowled the one over in his second spell

27.6   Dushmantha Chameera to Mommsen, no run, back of a length delivery just outside off, Mommsen hops in the crease, opens the face of the bat and pushes it to the right of backward point, shouts a loud 'no' for the single

Even as the Sri Lankan bowlers were hurrying through their overs, the heavens have opened up, it's just a slight drizzle at the moment, but with 20 overs not yet bowled, SL do not want to take a chance. A wash-out here will tie them with Bangladesh on 7 points. They have an inferior net run-rate as well. New Zealand play Bangladesh in their final match, a positive result or even a wash-out will push Sri Lanka to number four in Pool A, and that will mean a meeting with India in the quarter-finals. We need another 18 balls to be bowled for a result in this game..

Welcome back.. It's a tough chase for Scotland. They have acquitted themselves well in this tournament so far but haven't had a positive result to show for it. With no pressure, this is another chance to show their class and ability..

Dilshan: "I want to carry on this form for the next few games. If I get a start, I try to bat as long as possible. I had a chat with Marvan (Atapattu) and coaching staff as well. Great experience with Kumar (Sangakkara), he is a great player, both together we have more than fifteen 100 plus partnerships in the last few years. He is supporting me in the middle. Hopefully, we can forge more partnerships in the middle. If I'm scoring runs like now, I will carry on for a few more years. I'm enjoying my cricket at the moment and we will see after the World Cup where I can end up my career."

The Scottish bowlers were taken to the cleaners, but they will at least be happy with how they came back at the end. Otherwise, things would have been far worse for them. Also, not to forget they had a mixed day in the field, dropping a few chances, while taking a few difficult ones. Rob Taylor and Richie Berrington were the pick of the bowlers. Even though they didn't take the majority of the wickets, they didn't let the Sri Lankan batsmen dictate terms when they were bowling. Apart from them, Davey took 3 wickets, Evans took 2 and Machan chipped in with 1. It is going to be very difficult for Scotland to chase this down, but who knows if there's a surprise in store for us. The pitch is flat and very good for batting. Take a break and join us in a short while for the run-chase.

Captain Mathews and Kusal Perera, who were new at the crease, never let the aggressive intent fade away as both of them kept going after the bowling. Sri Lanka managed 57/3 from the batting powerplay, but both of them didn't stop there. They kept going after the bowling before Kusal Perera fell for a 13-ball 24. Mathews carried on his show and hit Machan for 4 consecutive sixes to notch up the second fastest fifty of this World Cup. However, he also perished off the very next ball, trying to make it 5 sixes in a row. Since then, batters came and went as Sri Lanka kept pushing for more runs towards the fag end of the innings. However, they lost 4 wickets in a space of 10 runs and that helped Scotland pull things back. Kulasekara hit a few lusty blows at the end and Sri Lanka finished with 363, the highest total against Scotland in an ODI.

At one stage both of them were on 99, but Dilshan was the first one to reach the landmark as he registered his 22nd ODI ton, his 4th in World Cups as well. After that came the big moment as Sangakkara became the first cricketer to hit 4 successive ODI hundreds. He also became the first man to score 4 hundreds in a single edition of the World Cup. Both Sanga and Dilshan then decided to take the batting powerplay in the 35th over. Sri Lanka didn't get off to the best of starts in the powerplay as Dilshan holed out to mid-off in the first over itself. Sanga then took the onus of going big and took 24 runs off Evans' 7th over, where he hit him for a six and 4 fours. While trying to make the maximum of the field restrictions, both Mahela Jayawardene and Kumar Sangakkara perished off consecutive deliveries, leaving Sri Lanka at 245/4 at the end of the 37th over. Davey, who took both those wickets, overtook Boult and became the highest wicket-taker of the tournament.

Sri Lanka didn't get off to the best of starts as Thirimanne went back early, trying to flash a drive against Evans. Dilshan was then joined by Sangakkara, who was chasing history, trying to become the first man to hit four consecutive tons in ODIs. Both the batsmen were then looking to stabilize the innings as they kept chipping away with singles, managing to put 46 on the board after 10 overs. After both Dilshan and Sanga got their eye in, both of them started dispatching the poor balls to the fence. The duo reached their fifties in quick succession and then decided to take the attack to the opposition, showing great footwork as they kept lofting the bowlers over the infield. The Scottish bowlers were not up to the task as both batsmen looked as if they were having a race between themselves so as to who reaches his hundred first.

33.6   Coetzer to Sangakkara, 2 runs, Sangaaaaaaaaaa! What.A.Playa! The first man ever in ODI history to make four tons in a row. Many have done it thrice. But no-one till today has got to that peak. What's more. He has done it in a World Cup. At the age of 37. In his last World Cup. Is there a better all-round player than this man in the world currently? Only AB de Villiers can lay claim to that title. Gets there with a steer to third man and takes a couple. Look at that celebration from him. No aggro, no brashness, no over-the-top shouting, no show of emotion. Just a calm face, removes the helmet and then raises the bat. Has a word with Dilshan. That's how to do it - if he wants to, he could bat on for the next three, four years - such is the form he is in at the moment. It was inevitable, the moment he came out to bat today against Scotland, that the record would be broken, without any disrespect shown to the Scots. Sanga is too good a player to miss out on such a golden chance to break a record that has stood there for a long time

The Scottish players have taken the field. Thirimanne and Dilshan make their way out to the centre. The former will take first strike. The countdown begins. Rob Taylor to start off. He has a couple of slips in place. Here we go..
Pitch Report: "The pitch looks glorious. There is a tinge of green. It looks solid. Win the toss, bat first and you can make hay on a pitch that looks good for batting," reckons Rameez Raja
Teams:
Scotland (Playing XI): Kyle Coetzer, Calum MacLeod, Matt Machan, Freddie Coleman, Preston Mommsen(c), Richie Berrington, Matthew Cross(w), Josh Davey, Rob Taylor, Michael Leask, Alasdair Evans

Sri Lanka (Playing XI): Lahiru Thirimanne, Tillakaratne Dilshan, Kumar Sangakkara(w), Mahela Jayawardene, Angelo Mathews(c), Kushal Janith Perera, Thisara Perera, Nuwan Kulasekara, Seekkuge Prasanna, Dushmantha Chameera, Lasith Malinga
Sri Lanka have won the toss and have opted to bat

Mommsen: "We would have batted. Looks a good one-day wicket. At the same time, I think it's quite hard a ground to defend on. So, nothing wrong in batting second. We have got three changes, Michael Leask comes in for Majid Haq, off-spinning option, Freddie Coleman and Rob Taylor come in as well. It has been an awesome experience, the first four games for us. We have played some good cricket and unfortunately we haven't been able to get that win. Nonetheless, though it is relatively new for us playing on this world stage and the boys are savouring every moment of it. I think definitely the atmosphere and pressure is amplified when you are playing at a World Cup, so I think each game we have become more relaxed and we have played better cricket as a result."

Mathews: "We will have a bat first. Of course it looks really nice and hard. So, we will put the runs on the board, nice conditions to bat first so we will get runs on the board first. It was a good game. I thought 340 would have been a chasable score, but unfortunately 370 was a bit too much, but hopefully we can go well today. Not really, we have been playing pretty good cricket in the past four games and we will look to continue to do that in today's game as well. Kusal (Perera) takes his (Chandimal) place and also we got two more changes. Sachitra (Senanayake) and Upul Tharanga goes out, we have got Nuwan Kulasekara, Chameera Dushmantha and Kusal Janith in. Of course he (Kulasekara) is one of the players we can bank on. So, we look to play him and hope he goes well. He (Sangakkara) is an unbelievable player, isn't he? I mean he has scored three hundreds in a row and hopefully he can get another one today."

Head-to-Head: Scotland have only played once against Sri Lanka and naturally it was the Asian team that came out on top. After setting a target of 285, Malinga blew away the Scottish batting line-up with a 5-wicket haul. Will the team winning the toss bat first or will they put the opposition in? We'll find out soon as the toss is on the way. Stay tuned!

Weather Check: It is a cool day in Hobart. There is a bit of cloud around. The maximum temperature is 23 degress. Even though it's cloudy, there are no chances of rain. Perfect weather to play a game of cricket.
Scotland

Scotland have had their moments in this tournament. Almost running New Zealand close while defending a paltry 142, losing a thriller against Afghanistan and their best game was the previous one versus Bangladesh. Kyle Coetzer played a magnificent innings to set up a massive 319. But, the bowlers could not contain the Bangladeshi batsmen as Tamim, Mahmudullah, Rahim and Shakib went onto get fifties and helped Bangladesh pull off the second highest successful run-chase in World Cup.

They have lost their games by not winning the key moments. In fact, the Scots are still searching for their first World Cup victory. They have the players who have been performing on an individual level, but the team hasn failed to stitch it together as a unit. The bowling looks settled with Wardlaw, Davey, Evans and Haq. The likes of Coetzer, Machan and Berrington have all scored fifties. But, still they have not contributed in unison. Can they win a game in this World Cup and leave a mark?
Sri Lanka

Sri Lanka didn't start off on the best of notes. They lost to New Zealand by a big margin and were put under tremendous pressure by Afghanistan. But, since then they have been in terrific form. They beat Bangladesh comprehensively, thanks to hundreds from Dilshan and Sangakkara. Once again riding on the back of a Sanga ton, they thrashed England and chased down 310. However, their previous game against Australia didn't pan out the way they wanted. Chasing 375, they were on course with a third ton from Sanga and some fireworks from Chandimal, before the latter had to retire hurt due to a hamstring injury. That tilted the match in Australia's favour and eventually, Australia won by 64 runs.

That defeat should be forgotten quickly as they give Australia a run for their money. They can take heart from the fact that they became the first team to score 300 versus Australia in a World cup game. Nonetheless, Sri Lanka are a side that is suffering from a lot of injury woes. Dinesh Chandimal is the latest addition to their injury list, which already included, Dhammika Prasad, Jeevan Mendis, Dimuth Karunaratne. Kusal Perera has been drafted in as a replacement for Chandimal. With so many players injured, Sri Lanka are yet to decide upon their final XI. So, this game will given them an opportunity to test their best combination before the quarter-finals.

13:15 Local Time, 02:15 GMT, 07:45 IST: On Monday, Bangladesh created history at the Adelaide Oval. By beating England, they ensured their qualification for the knockouts for the first time. That win also took Sri Lanka through to the quarterfinals. The Islanders currently have 6 points in 5 games and today they will be up against a spirited Scottish team. Let us just have a recap as to what these two teams have been doing lately.

Preview:

After the final over thriller on Saturday between Ireland and Zimbabwe, the Bellerive Oval in Hobart will play host to Sri Lanka's final group stage game. Having already been assured of a place in the quarter-finals following Bangladesh's historic win, an injury-hit Sri Lanka take on Scotland looking to finalize their combination ahead of the crucial knockout phase. Scotland, despite putting in spirited performances, find themselves without a win in four games, with Sri Lanka and Australia to play. The game also assumes importance to determine Sri Lanka's potential quarter-final opponent. A Sri Lanka win will take them above Bangladesh, who are yet to play New Zealand, and potentially avoid a clash with the table-toppers from Pool B (India).

Team News:

Sri Lanka

Sri Lanka's injury woes were exacerbated when Dinesh Chandimal hobbled out of the Australia game and the World Cup with a hamstring injury. A significant blow considering he had just scored a 22-ball half-century. Since the start of the warmup games, Sri Lanka have lost Dhammika Prasad, Jeevan Mendis, Dimuth Karunaratne and now Chandimal. Left-arm spinner Rangana Herath, who suffered an injury to his finger during the England game has not sufficiently recovered and is unlikely to recover before the quarters. Kusal Perera has been drafted into the squad while Kithruwan Vithanage has been flown in as cover. Amidst all the injury trouble, a 37-year old Kumar Sangakkara became the first man to score three consecutive World Cup centuries when he scored the 104 at the SCG. Dilshan, Jayawardene, Thirimanne have all scored hundreds but the bowling, especially in the middle overs, remains an area of concern. The trio of Angelo Mathews, Thissara Perera and Seekkuge Prasanna gave away 223 runs in their 26 overs against Australia. The think-tank would consider bringing back Suranga Lakmal to reinforce the bowling department.

Probable XI:

Lahiru Thirimanne, Tillakaratne Dilshan, Kumar Sangakkara (wk), Mahela Jayawardene, Angelo Mathews (c), Upul Tharanga, Thissara Perera, Kusal Perera/Nuwan Kulasekara, Seekkuge Prasanna, Sachithra Senanayake, Lasith Malinga

Player to watch out for: Angelo Mathews - The captain had been the star of Sri Lanka coming in to the World Cup. However, with the Sangakkara-led top-order firing on all cylinders, Mathews hasn't had enough time with the bat. Even with the ball, he endured a forgettable game against the Aussies. Look forward to an improved showing from the versatile Sri Lankan captain.

Scotland

Scotland travel to Tasmania without a win in any of the four games in their New Zealand sojourn. They haven't been completely woeful either. They succeeded in sending jitters down the red-hot New Zealand side despite defending a small score. Against Afghanistan, they came up against an inspired Samiullah Shenwari, who took the game away from them. The biggest worry for Scotland has been that they haven't succeeded in putting a solid all-round performance, a fact highlighted in their previous game against Bangladesh. Kyle Coetzer's 158 (record for associate nations in World Cups) received no backing from the bowling and Bangladesh chased down 318 at a canter. Matt Machan, Richie Berrington have been good with the bat, without being great. Preston Mommsen will hope for one of the middle-order batsmen to carry on and make it big. Lead bowler Iain Wardlaw has been disappointing in the tournament and will hope for an improved showing. Wardlaw, Josh Davey and Co. now face the daunting prospect of bowling at a marauding Sri Lankan top-order. At the least, they will be expected to put in another spirited show as their World Cup winds down.

Probable XI:

Kyle Coetzer, Calum MacLeod, Hamish Gardiner, Matt Machan, Preston Mommsen (c), Richie Berrington, Matthew Cross (wk), Josh Davey, Majid Haq, Alasdair Evans, Iain Wardlaw

Player to watch out for: Preston Mommsen - The Scottish captain hasn't found the going easy with the bat. His 39 against Bangladesh took his World Cup tally to a meagre 88 runs. He will look to prove a point in the team's two remaining clashes.

Pitch and Conditions:

The Bellerive Oval hosted the Ireland-Zimbabwe thriller in which 657 runs were scored. Despite being a tad two-paced, the short square boundaries prove to be a handful to defend. Sri Lankan batsmen should enjoy themselves on the Hobart pitch. The forecast indicate a 20% chance of rain but the showers are unlikely to force a washout.

Stats and Trivia:

- Kumar Sangakkara is the first man to score three successive World Cup centuries.
- Kyle Coetzer needs 29 runs to become the third Scotland player to score 1000 ODI runs. Gavin Hamilton and Neil McCallum are the others.

Quotes:

"We've been in a couple of winning positions, and just maybe through lack of experience on playing at this stage, we've not been able to win those games"
- Scotland captain Preston Mommsen cited inexperience for his team's failure to close out games.

"There are big game players and he's (Lasith Malinga) one of those. He stands up and he has a big game and in pressure situations, he comes up trumps"
- Sri Lankan coach Marvan Atapattu was happy with the progress made by his strike bowler post his injury.
